QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND GOVERNMENT: INTERNATIONAL LABOUR ORGANISATION CONVENTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the Queensland Government has denied that its recent industrial legislation breaches any International Labour Organisation convention? Can the Minister advise the House of the exact situation in that regard? How serious are such breaches?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the claims by the Queensland Government that it is not in breach of ILO conventions. There is no doubt on the part of the Government that the Queensland Government is in breach of a number of ILO conventions. Strong advice has been received from the Attorney-General's Department to that effect. Very briefly, the three areas of breach relate to the excessive powers of the Electricity Commissioner, which breach ILO conventions 29, l05 and 98; the lack of appeal rights for electricity workers to an independent authority regarding dismissal for being on strike, which is in breach of ILO Convention 87; and the accelerated deregistration provisions which do not allow for appeal to an independent authority against deregistration of the unions, which also is in breach of Convention 87. It is interesting to note that the breaching of two of those ILO conventions-Convention 29 and Convention 87 respectively-have been cited against the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Poland in recent years. That is the company in which the Queensland Government now is.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government regards these breaches as extremely serious. They are breaches of international treaties and they are also breaches of a very long-standing bipartisan support in this country for the ILO amongst political parties and, beyond that, the industrial parties, unions and employers. These breaches are made more serious by the Federal Opposition's support for the Queensland breaches and by the statements by the Opposition spokesmen that the ILO conventions are totally irrelevant to Australia's industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear a few cries of 'Hear, hear!' in support of that. I think that is a disgrace for the Federal Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Tripartite support for the ILO by governments, unions and employers has been demonstrated by a long involvement with the ILO of all three parties. Ratification of ILO conventions is part of that involvement. There is also, of course, each year an annual conference of the ILO to which Australia sends a tripartite delegation. That delegation often includes the Minister and it has been a long-standing practice for the Minister to invite a State labour Minister and also the Federal Opposition spokesman to accompany him. In recent years membership of this delegation has included such people as, in l98l, the Queensland Minister for Employment and Labour Relations, Sir William Knox, which presumably indicated the support for the ILO by the Queensland Government at that time. The Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, now the spokesman on foreign affairs, went to the ILO in l983 and l984. Under the previous Government three Ministers went to the ILO, presumably representing support by that Government for the ILO. They were Ministers Street, Viner and Hunt. When Minister Viner went to the ILO conference, he said:
I reaffirm Australia's strong and continuing support for the ILO and what it stands for.

In l982 the now Deputy Leader of the National Party went as a visiting Minister to the ILO, representing the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. On behalf of the Government, he said:
We call upon member States to respect the principle of freedom of association . . .

That is Convention No. 87, of which the Queensland Government is now in breach on at least two counts. Against all that, we now have statements by the Opposition spokesman that ILO conventions are totally irrelevant, that he thinks the ILO would be much better served by looking at some of the labour practices of the Third World nations and some of the communist nations instead of worrying about a democratic country like Australia, and that he thinks it is nonsense to invoke ILO conventions in respect of the Electrical Trades Union dispute in Queensland. All those statements are highly regrettable in terms of breaking down that bipartisan support. But we do not regard it as a lost cause. I certainly hope that the Opposition will change its mind on this matter. The Government hopes that it will repudiate those statements and accept support for the ILO. In that connection, I have today, in accordance with longstanding practice, sent a letter to the Opposition spokesman inviting him to attend the next conference of the ILO with me. I hope he will demonstrate his support for the ILO by accepting that invitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that the Human Rights Commission has found the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act to be in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commission has examined that appropriate bit of legislation. Human Rights Commission Report No. l2 which was tabled in this Parliament last week stated that the Human Rights Commission had found that that legislation was inconsistent with Article 8 of the International Covenant. It further recommended that the inconsistencies in that legislation be brought to the attention of the Queensland Government.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a serious matter. The Human Rights Commission was established by the Fraser Government. The Commission has a responsibility to ensure that the International Covenant is adhered to. From the point of view of Queensland's involvement in that adherence, it is a matter of record that between l972 and l980, when the Covenant was ratified, the Queensland Government was continually consulted. It agreed to the International Covenant being ratified. Having agreed to it, the Queensland Government is bound by it.

If we look at the particular piece of legislation we see that it has some horrendous provisions in it, namely, those in respect of the electricity commissioner. He can direct any person to do work, irrespective of whether that person is an employee or not. Of course, if the person who is bound under section 3 to become an employee fails to carry out the direction, that person can be dismissed summarily and also fined $l,000. Further, the jurisdiction of the State Industrial Commission was excluded.

What I have to say to this Parliament is that we have an International Covenant which obliges State governments to comply with the Covenant. Indeed, with their co-operation, the Covenant was ratified on that basis. The Human Rights Commission has said that that matter should be brought to the attention of the Premier of Queensland. Of course, I am aware that it has been brought to his attention by correspondence from the Prime Minister. All the Premier could do was say that he would ignore the correspondence. He might ignore the correspondence but he cannot ignore the fact that there has been a breach of the International Covenant.

The real issue we are talking about here is the obligation to ensure that legislation complies with that Covenant. Here is a breach of it. There is no need to be in breach of the Covenant. One can run an intelligent democracy without having to breach the Covenant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to take action ?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor has had a pretty good go since 2 o'clock. I warn him.

—The point at issue is this: The Queensland Government legislated to override conditions of employment; it legislated to terminate the jurisdiction of the Industrial Commission; it legislated in a sense to prevent the employees from negotiating terms and conditions in the normal atmosphere of conciliation and arbitration which applied under the previous Queensland law. What government in any democratic nation would want to legislate to prevent its own laws from operating and to legislate in direct breach of an international covenant? No other government in Australia would do so and no other government in the Western democracies would do so because it is a breach of normal democratic standards. That is the point that now bedevils this nation. With that sort of legislation and that sort of Premier, it is natural, is it not, that we will have industrial disputation? Accordingly, everybody in the nation must bear the burden of that reckless type of legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The real issue, of course, is for the Queensland Government to adhere to normal international standards. If it is a democracy, why does the Queensland Government not legislate in accordance with those standards? If it is so concerned about industrial disputation, why does it not adhere to the fact that under the International Covenant there are obligations to have conciliation and arbitration? It has been made very clear today that honourable gentlemen opposite do not see any merit in the International Covenant, but they see a lot of merit in the sort of legislation that has been foisted upon Queensland. I say to the honourable member for Brisbane that what he says, of course, is very evident to many people in Australia. If that sort of conduct goes on, if it is permissible simply because one has the numbers in the Parliament and can breach a covenant, is it any wonder that there is industrial disputation? Is it any wonder that there are industrial disputes that spread across the length and breadth of this continent?

In the Constitution there are provisions to settle by conciliation and arbitration disputes which extend beyond the bounds of any one State. At this stage the dispute has been confined to Queensland. Regrettably, the Premier has taken the view that he will legislate his way out of the dispute. He will never be able to legislate his way out of the dispute. The real issue is the question of conciliation and arbitration in accordance with international standards. It is about time that the Queensland Government, irrespective of its Premier, realised that it has an obligation under that Covenant. I am sure that the people of Queensland understand that point, as do the more thinking members of the Opposition. If it becomes a question of legislating in the way in which members of the Opposition want to legislate, peace and industrial harmony in Australia will go out the window. We will again draw to the attention of the Queensland Government-not necessarily the Premier, but the Government-the fact that there is an international obligation to be adhered to. All that the Premier has to do is to repeal that legislation. Unless he does so he will be in continual breach of the International Covenant.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the Prime Minister's answer to the Leader of the Opposition, I ask him: What would have been the total expenditure required to continue the Government's l984-85 policies in l985-86 without the $l billion reduction?
—A billion more than it would otherwise have been.
—I regret that the Special Minister of State has given the answer for me. He has just said: 'A billion more than it would otherwise have been'.
—My question also is addressed to the Prime Minister. What do he and the Government consider to be the most satisfactory and permanent way of resolving the Queensland power industry dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I believe that all who are seriously concerned with this issue, and not merely involved in attempts at cheap political point-scoring, will realise that the essential requirement for the settlement of this issue-not just the immediate dispute but for the settlement of this issue in the longer term-is the creation of conditions in which there will be an assurance in the minds of members of the Queensland public that they will have continuity of supplies in the electricity industry. That is the essential issue. The people of Queensland and the Government of Queensland are entitled to be concerned about trying to achieve that situation. Unfortunately, all that has been offered in this regard is draconian legislation which will not, in the short, medium or long term, give a satisfactory assurance on this central matter.

ANSWER.PARA: As I told the House in speaking on this issue earlier, what is required is that the parties sit down and negotiate a settlement of disputes procedure, the sort of procedure to which organised employers, the trade union movement and governments have directed their minds in the past. In order that Opposition members, to the extent they have any real interest in this subject, and the Government of Queensland may have some understanding of the precise sort of thing we are talking about, I indicate to the House that the features of an effective dispute settlement procedure would include the following sorts of provisions. The provisions to which I refer have the significance that they were arrived at in the National Labour Advisory Council in the early l970s. They were agreed to by representatives of the employers, the trade unions and the Federal Government. The then Government-the non-Labor Government-the organised employers and the trade unions addressed themselves to this issue: What sort of settlement of disputes procedure should one think about? What are the elements of it that should be laid down to ensure that, particularly in essential industries, there will be a mechanism to make sure that there will be continuity of supplies?

The elements of such a settlement of disputes procedure are that there should be a lengthy cooling-off period in the event of a dispute arising. There should be clearly understood procedures for dealing with matters in dispute. These would be promulgated to management at all levels, to union representatives, including at the plant or local level, and to all employees. There would be a clear and unequivocal commitment by all parties to the implementation of the letter and intent of the agreed procedures. It would also provide for special attention to be given in formulating agreed procedures for safety issues. There would be capacity at any stage of the agreed procedures for the parties to seek the assistance of a conciliator, the relevant industrial tribunal or some other mutually acceptable person. There would be no recourse to formal arbitration processes until all the agreed avenues for dealing with disputes which arise have been exhausted. Normal working would continue at all stages of the dispute settlement process, except where there were serious issues of the safety of workers.

It is quite clear that that outline of a settlement of disputes procedure of the sort that was arrived at under the auspices of a non-Labor government, in consultation with organised employers and the trade union movement, offers a very tight situation. I can say that the trade unions concerned would agree to such an extremely tight procedure in which the possibility of strike action would be virtually excluded. I trust that, I having outlined those relevant elements of a settlement of disputes procedure, the Government of Queensland will see that the way to settle this dispute in a way that will serve the interests of the people of Queensland and ensure the guarantee of continuity of supplies is to sit down now and negotiate with the unions. We are prepared to be involved and to provide our good services in seeing that there can be a resumption of normal work with such a settlement of disputes procedure.

—Will the Minister for Health advise the House of the progress of the introduction of acquired immune deficiency syndrome screening kits into Australia? How successful will the introduction of the kits be in minimising the spread of AIDS?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for his question. I am glad to be able to say that as of today all States and Territories have now announced arrangements for the use of the AIDS antibody screening tests. Throughout Australia, all nominated State health laboratories and blood transfusion centres will be fully operational in their use of the screening tests by next Monday. South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland began full use of the tests last Monday week. Since then, Tasmania and the Northern Territory have become operational. Today, New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory announced the nominated laboratories to which at risk people could go for screening from next Monday.

ANSWER.PARA: The speedy introduction of the screening tests represents a tremendous co-operative effort between the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, the Red Cross and the scientific community in combating what is a major public health problem in this country. It has been a major task involving co-ordinated evaluation of the kits, tendering and purchase, the installation of testing equipment and the training of laboratory personnel to evaluate test results. All States and Territories, the Red Cross and the scientific community deserve congratulations for the quick and efficient introduction of these kits.

I point out that this makes Australia the first country to have fully introduced the AIDS screening tests. We in fact will be providing from Monday next a more comprehensive coverage than the United States of America, the country which is supplying the kits. The kits have been distributed simultaneously to Red Cross blood banks and to public health laboratories throughout Australia. This has been done because those in high risk groups who wish to be tested for AIDS should not go to the blood banks but should use the laboratories nominated by the governments in their State or Territory. In addition, general practitioners and private pathologists will also be able to collect blood from patients and forward supplies to the nominated laboratories.

The Government believes that, with an almost l00 per cent accuracy of the test for the AIDS anti-body, this is the best means yet to prevent the spread of AIDS through our blood supply. The Commonwealth Government has now given some $5.4m since November last to State health departments, community organisations, the blood transfusion service and other organisations, in a combined effort to halt the spread of this disease. Some $2.5m of that money was put aside to pay for the 300,000 tests which it is anticipated will take place in this financial year. As of today, there have been 74 confirmed cases of AIDS in Australia, with 27 deaths so far. While the incidence of AIDS is clearly on the increase, we are confident that the decisive actions taken will help to contain what is one of the biggest public health problems this country has had to face.

As you know, Mr Speaker, for many years there has been a philosophic debate going on in Australia over the continuation of the imperial honours as against the institution under the Whitlam Government of the Australian honours system, which we believe in and which we think has now been consolidated and accepted by the vast majority of people as being the proper awards to be given to Australians. Of course, it may be that Sunday's attacks of the killer tomatoes have got to him. It may also be that beyond the problems of the Victorian Labor Party there is a recognition that it is not the Australian people, to whom he is appealing to tighten their belts, who have been profligate but this Government, which has been profligate throughout.

The only answer that could be given to any questions today relating to the so-called $l billion cut in the forward estimates was that $l billion has been taken from what there was before but which is not there now. If honourable members can interpret what that leads to in terms of consistent economic management they are doing better than the Government itself. The Prime Minister's statement yesterday on the so-called $l billion expenditure cut is a further sign of the bankruptcy of the Government. It has a bankruptcy in ideas, a bankruptcy in courage and even, as Mr Kelty puts it, a bankruptcy in vision and direction. Instead of responding to the real problems of the economy the Prime Minister's response yesterday-as incomprehensible as his response today-was an endeavour in public relations. The days in which such an endeavour was successful for this man are now past. So-called tough talk is no substitute for tough action. The time for blaming someone else, indeed everyone else-in his words, the 'irresponsible community', the 'irrational money markets', the 'ungrateful Labor Premiers' or the 'mythical $9.6m deficit'-is gone.

This man stands bereft of policy and the only people suffering are those whom he is supposed to be administering, namely, the Australian people. The bungles continue and the results are there for all to see. The Australian dollar has hit new lows, despite the highest interest rates in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development area and despite gross domestic product figures showing significant growth in the last quarter of l984.

That is the background to yesterday's unsubstantiated statement that the Government intends to reduce expenditure by $l billion from some unknown baseline figures in some unreleased and unknown forward estimates. There is one test of whether someone is fair dinkum in trying to convince one that what he is doing is correct-that is, is he telling the details and is he telling the truth? We have not been told anything which would give us a marker to test whether what the Government is saying is correct. We have had unknown baseline figures, unreleased and unknown forward estimates. There has been no check on the statements made by the Government, and, despite constant questioning today, no further information.

The fact is that the statement made yesterday was the act of a very desperate man. I said I was sorry to hear that he had a cold. I repeat: I was unaware that that cold had taken residence in his feet. But he gave verbal evidence of that both yesterday and today. There was a belated attempt to create the impression of being in control; an attempt to shore up confidence in a directionless, failing government and a failing economic strategy; and an attempt to compensate for the confusion and the conflict which are now the hallmark of the Hawke Government. It is a government, which as I say, in the words of Bill Kelty-they are not my words; the sorcerer's apprentice himself came out with the words-which appeared on the front page of the Australian Financial Review, lacks vision and has lost direction.

The response of the Government in yesterday's half-baked statement was not the required comprehensive review of its economic strategy and not the required bench-mark against which to measure the purported expenditure cuts. It had all the signs of a hastily prepared, desperate statement. As I say, it was an exercise in public relations. Quite frankly, although all Australians at this moment feel justifiably concerned about the dollar, I think the overwhelming majority of them accept the floating of the dollar. We do. We do not now-as the Prime Minister has done-having given it to the market to make a judgment, call into question that market's judgment. We respect the decision that was taken. But Australians want to know: What is the truth about the so-called fundamentals of the economy upon which the market is making its judgment? What is the program that will at least start to correct these fundamental weaknesses in the economy? Where is the clear sign that this Government will break away from union control over its economic decision making process?

The fact is that not only have those fundamental weaknesses been masked over by the endeavour of this Government over the last six months, but they were created by this very Government, by the combination of failed economic management and a failure to be able to recognise and-again I say it-tell the truth. This was a feature of yesterday's statement and a consistent feature of the lack of answers in this Parliament today. The ridicule that members on this side of the Parliament heaped on the Prime Minister is symptomatic of the ridicule directed towards the man in the public arena. It is not confined to the lunatic Left in his Party; it is spreading into the community. This desperate endeavour was brought about because he has twigged to the fact that he has been unable to explain any central purpose for the Government. Yet he had the gall to tell the Australian people that it was the Australian community who 'cannot simply go on running up debts and living beyond its means'. This was stated by the man who leads the biggest spending, highest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history.

The Prime Minister will not give details of the so-called belt tightening. Everyone else out there must do that, but he will not give any reason: Blame the Australian people-dump it on them. But they are not the profligates. It is this Government that has been profligate. It is the Government now, it alleges, which will slam on the brakes. But the runaway lorry the Prime Minister seeks to bring under control is the Government itself, or it ought to be.

It is important that every Australian understands the real background to yesterday's statement. This Government-not the Australian people-has been living beyond its means. If one goes into the community-and members of the Opposition know this-one sees a significant growth in the number of people who are finding it difficult to cope out there. Let not the Prime Minister tell them they have to tighten their belts when this Government continues its high taxing policies, when it impacts on the community all the on-costs, taxes and charges that make this the highest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history. Let him not come in here and tell those people, who are struggling day after day, week after week to make their ends meet, that they will be the ones who will have to tighten up. It is the Labor Government which has created this situation, not people out there who are depending on this Government for a blueprint and vision which this Government has not called forth in Australia. It is this Government that is profligate. It is this Government that budgeted to increase real expenditure by 6.l per cent in l984-85 following the 7.7 per cent increase in l983-84. And it is this Government that increased Budget outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product from 29.9 per cent in l982-83 to 3l.l per cent in l984-85. Those wild Whitlamesque expenditure increases in the last Budget represented an increase of $l.3 billion for the so-called new policy initiatives. Only eight months later the Government now says it will take back one billion of it. What kind of economic management is that?

Let us make no mistake about it, the Opposition has always said, and continues to say, that major expenditure cuts are required. The point is that Australia should never have been in the position where, to paraphrase the Treasurer (Mr Keating), it has the world's fastest growing economy and the world's fastest sinking currency; where recovery is being blunted by real interest rates which are the highest in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development area and the highest in Australia since the Second World War; where it has the second highest current account deficit in the OECD area; where it has the highest money supply growth of any major OECD country, and where it is the only OECD country with full wage indexation. These are the fundamentals of the economy, yet the Prime Minister keeps trying to hide the truth. In the election campaign some six months ago the Prime Minister falsely boasted:
Never in the last decade-and more-has there been anything like the combination of favourable circumstances that now exist.
Only last week the Prime Minister again stuck his head in the sand by claiming:
The fundamentals of the Australian economy are stronger than virtually any other economy in the world.

What was the response of the market to that? It was total disbelief. We saw what transpired thereafter. One statement of vague, unsubstantiated intent about expenditure cuts will never restore confidence.

Let me tell the House what the Opposition would do and what we say is needed. What is needed is a set of decisive commitments and actions, including, first, a clear statement that the Government will support discounting of wage indexation for the effects of devaluation; secondly, a clear statement that the Government will oppose any wage increases for productivity increases; thirdly, a clear direction for monetary policy and the reinstatement of monetary targeting as soon as is feasible; fourthly, a clear commitment by the Prime Minister to achieving tax reform; fifthly, a warning to the Australian Council of Trade Unions that the Government will take action against any industrial action of the type being taken against Queensland and specific companies supporting the Queensland Government; sixthly, a list of substantial expenditure cuts, backed up by substantial evidence that they are real cuts.

We can lay it down. These are the minimum requirements to restore confidence. They are the statements that could have been made yesterday, that should have been made yesterday and that should have been forthcoming in the Parliament today. It is no longer enough for the Prime Minister to run the economy on the so-called accord for his own imagined accolades. The time has come for the Government to tell the truth and in fact admit the failure to date. Until that happens Australia's underlying economic problems and the loss of confidence will remain to damage not just the Government but the interests of all Australians.

It was this Prime Minister who talked up the economy. Throughout the election campaign it was this Prime Minister who told Australians that they had never had it so good. It was this Prime Minister who said that interest rates would fall throughout l985. It was this Prime Minister who failed to tell Australians the truth. I say to this House that he is not telling the truth today and that he was not telling the truth yesterday. It is this Prime Minister who, having floated the dollar, blames the market for its interpretation of his actions-actions beyond economic actions. It is this Prime Minister who ought to be coming into this chamber, not with exhortations and misleading rhetoric, but with a blueprint and a schedule akin to the matters I have spelt out today. Profligacy is the Government's sin, not the people's. Whether it be on monetary supply, budgetary policy or wages policy, this Government has failed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me examine a little more the credentials of our opponents who are trying to criticise this Government. From l979-80 to l982-83 in the last four Budgets over which he presided, we actually saw a growth in outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product. When examining our statements, particularly on budgetary matters, one must examine our record compared with the appalling, deplorable record of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. He was not able to stick to his monetary targets in any year. The majority of his Budgets blew out, in terms of both the deficit and outlays, from what had been budgeted for. Not only did that happen; we also saw a disintegrating economy during the years of his abysmal mismanagement. On the other hand, this Government has ensured a strengthening economy. Wherever we look, we see signs of strengthening growth. We have had an increase of 340,000 jobs since we came to government and a decline in the unemployment rate. This is the kind of economy for which we are now being called to account by these economic vandals who, when they were in office, saw the economy disintegrating beneath them and, more importantly, saw our international competitiveness decline and our trade performance decline dramatically as well. We decided that the only reasonable thing to do with the economy of this country was to expose it to the harsh light of international competition. That is a course on which we are determined to continue. Indeed, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have said-I am happy to add my voice as well-we will not see gains created by the devaluation frittered away in any way. The Minister for Trade, who has just left the chamber, has a colossal gall coming into Parliament and saying that the Opposition adopts a negative attitude and that it is sabotaging the Government. Yesterday we heard the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, waxing lyrical about the market realities of import parity pricing and how important it is that we be tough and resolute and that we face the outside world. What happened when we were in government? What did the Labor Party say about import parity pricing? It took the short term, politically opportunistic path of total blind obstruction. Not only has this Government been very fortuitous-a fact acknowledged by the Minister for Trade-but it has built much of its economic rhetoric over the last couple of years on two giant deceptions. The reality is that the back of Australia's high inflation rate was broken by a combination of the 9 per cent cut in real wages produced by the wages pause and the normally depressing effect on prices of an economic recession. The wages accord did not come into operation until September l983 and it did not start to have a beneficial effect on the price index until well into l984. However, the greatest deception of all is the claim that the Government inherited an unmanageable deficit of $9.6 billion. As I listened to the former Minister for Finance stuttering and stammering to the end of his speech, I remembered that the second last Budget we brought down had a deficit of a bare $548m, 0.4 per cent of gross domestic product. Two years ago the forward estimates of expenditure and revenue were holy writ, one year ago they were illusory and this year they are totally non-existent. In other words, figures that had to be published two years ago are now so unbelievable, so irrelevant, so illusory and so meaningless that they cannot be published. DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Introduction

This is an historic day for the Federal Government in Australia. For the first time a concerted national effort is being made to come to grips with the problems of occupational health and safety in the community. This Bill which I have introduced in the House today is the first of three. The others will be presented at a later date. One will relate to general duties of care and regulations in respect of occupational health and safety in areas of Commonwealth jurisdiction including the Australian Capital Territory, external Territories and areas of Commonwealth employment. The other will relate to the establishment of a mandatory notification and assessment scheme for industrial chemicals. The Bill before the House is the product of sustained dialogue with the States and Territories, employers and unions and has been developed in a spirit of full co-operation and with a recognition of the appropriate areas of responsibility of all parties.

The level of consensus makes this Bill a unique document. Representatives of both the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry have been in agreement at all stages of development of the national focus and strategy. As well, the Opposition has indicated its support on two previous occasions. The Government welcomed this support and trusts that it will continue.
Background

In presenting this Bill I want to repeat part of what I said in November of 1983 when announcing the establishment of an Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I said on that occasion that one of the most important and far-reaching policy proposals to which the Labor Government was committed was a national strategy on occupational health and safety. The nation as a whole is incurring enormous losses from unsafe and unhealthy working environments. Individual employees suffer the hardship of physical pain, disabilities and loss of income. Employers bear losses through reduced output and higher workers' compensation insurance premiums. The community as a whole faces higher prices and taxes to meet the spiralling costs of occupational injury and ill health. Conservative estimates are that more than $6 billion a year is wasted through loss of production and associated costs because of occupational injury and ill health. About 300 people are killed each year in work-related accidents and a further 150,000 people are injured at work each year. This is a gigantic social, human and economic penalty that can be reduced significantly only by concerted action on a national scale and this Bill represents the first substantial legislation by a Federal government to bring about a change for the better in the working environment.

The origins of this Bill derive from the Government's efforts comprehensively to implement Australian Labor Party policy in this area. This led to the establishment of the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in 1983. In May 1984 I tabled the report of the Interim Commission as a first step towards achieving a national focus and plan of action for occupational health and safety on the broadest possible scale-an issue, we believe honourable members will agree, transcends party politics because at the heart of the matter is the health and well-being of everyone in the work force and his or her family.

For too long occupational disease, injury and death have been seen as an almost inevitable part of the human and social cost of production. Companies must produce an adequate return and often the company that is only marginally economic is also the one with the worst problems in the health and safety area. There is often not enough incentive within an organisation to improve health and safety conditions because a great deal of the cost of illness, injury or death is borne by the community at large-medical, nursing and hospital costs, lifetime care for the permanently disabled worker and the value, in national terms, of lost production. To this has to be added the almost incalculable personal and human cost when an employee suffers injury, illness or death. Although the top management of a company may believe in principle that it is in the long term interests of the company to adopt sound health and safety practices, it may at the same time assess the short term performance of its middle management by production measurement criteria that could result in injury and other incidence rates higher than they would otherwise be. Such commitment at the senior level must be translated into action through all levels of management and on the shop floor. This is one reason why a national focus and strategy is so necessary. If the nation is to enhance the working environment, not only to improve the health and safety of its citizens but also to enjoy the very real economic and social benefits that are available, there has to be a concerted and co-ordinated national effort.

The problems the Bill sets out to alleviate are many and varied, and include that of inadequate knowledge and the poor transmission, access and utilisation of the knowledge that is available. Larger firms are often able to obtain information and, perhaps more importantly, know where to seek information and assistance, but smaller companies have a more difficult task. This lack of co-ordination between the various elements making up the work environment highlights the need for much better reporting systems and co-operation at all levels. Health and safety hazards are so numerous and diverse that it is beyond the practical confines of a second reading speech to detail them all-and new ones are being identified all the time. For instance, there are thousands of materials of known toxicity in commercial use already, and all the signs are that this number will keep pace with developing technology. But even the most common hazards represent a threat, and therefore a challenge, to the community.

The community's goal-and consequently that of the Government-must be to reduce the unacceptably high national level of occupational death, injury and illness. This objective is not just something the Government sees as desirable, something that everyone is in favour of for its own sake. It is a soundly-based economic objective as well as a socially desirable one. Improvement in working conditions is a basic goal of the prices and incomes accord and a national safety strategy is therefore an essential component of the non-wage aspect of the accord.

The success of any national health and safety strategy rests heavily on the commitment of employers, employees and their respective organisations and governments to an equitable system based on the principles of participation and acceptance of appropriate responsibility. Finally, it is up to employers and employees to bring about necessary improvements.

Central to this is our commitment to consultation and co-operation with State and Territory governments, the trade unions, employers and their organisations, occupational health and safety specialists and community groups. This consultation led to the establishment by the Government of a non-statutory National Occupational Health and Safety Commission with representatives of Federal, State and Territory governments, employers and unions in October, 1984 following acceptance of the main recommendations of the Interim Commission. Since then it has initiated positive action in priority areas such as chemicals, information, repetition strain injury and training. As well, the transfer of relevant senior administrative and specialist staff from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Health to the Commission has been completed.
Aims and Objectives

This Bill provides for the statutory national commission to be tripartite in nature because it is the Government's clear belief that progress can best be achieved through the close co-operation and involvement of employer and employee peak councils and Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. The Bill underlines the Commission's primary role of co-ordination and facilitation, with the major jurisdiction over occupational health and safety remaining with the States, some of which have recently taken significant initiatives in this field. It will still be up to each State to implement standards within its own jurisdiction. The National Commission will be required to report annually to the Minister and at that time the Minister will provide the House with a report on progress throughout Australia on the implementation of declared national standards.

The roles and responsibilities of the States, Territories and the Commonwealth are clear and distinct and the Bill does not seek to transfer any of these. The Bill specifically sets up the Commission within the limits of the constitutional power afforded to the Federal Government. It will enable the Commission to undertake additional beneficial activities in the fields of standards development, research, training and information collection and dissemination at a national level, thus representing a positive initiative in co-operative federalism.

There are about 160 Acts and ordinances relating to occupational health and safety and this is one of the areas where the Commission will seek to work with State and Territory governments towards the introduction of national standards. It has been recognised on many occasions that there exists a serious deficiency in our Australian occupational health and safety systems in the lack of a uniform reporting system. The new Commission has the important task to develop and implement such a data base. Only then will it be possible objectively to determine the national priorities.

The objectives of the establishment of the Commission are, in brief: The development among the community of an awareness of issues relating to occupational health and safety matters and facilitation of public debate on them; the provision of a forum where all parties can consult and debate matters pertinent to the subject; and development of a national focus for activities. The functions of the Commission as envisaged by the Bill will include such things as the formulation of policies and strategies on occupational health and safety matters; recommendations on co-operation with Commonwealth, State and Territory governments and groups and individuals engaged in occupational health and safety matters; the declaration of national standards and codes of practice; research; testing; training; funding; and provision of information. This will ensure that all Australians, regardless of language and occupation, have an opportunity to participate in the promotion of a safer and healthier working environment. A fund to be known as the National Occupational Health and Safety Research Fund will be set up under the Bill and the Commission will be empowered to provide funds for research projects relevant to occupational health and safety measures. The existence of this Fund will enhance the Commission's ability to attract funds from the public and private sectors so as to ensure a co-ordinated approach to research in priority areas.

The Commission will not limit itself to investigations and research within Australia but will seek to participate in the international transfer of ideas and information and to draw on the expertise of such bodies as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the World Health Organisation and the International Labour Organisation. There is an additional reason for intensifying the information links with such bodies-the development of internationally accepted work practices. This in turn can have a distinct economic as well as social benefit for Australia. Thus we need to work for international agreements so as to level out the impact of appropriate standards worldwide and so enhance the emergence of higher productivity, decreased absenteeism and improved work safety stemming from the encouragement of new technology, substitute materials and redesigned jobs.

It is the Government's intention, and indeed it was the firm recommendation of the Interim Commission, that Australia should work toward ratification of ILO convention 155, 'occupational safety and health and the working environment'. The members of Australia's tripartite delegations to the 66th and 67th sessions of the International Labour Organisation conferences held in 1980 and 1981 participated in the formation of convention 155 and its associated recommendation 164. Though there is not yet full compliance with the provisions by the Commonwealth and all State governments we believe the successful introduction of the national strategy need not be delayed by this and indeed represents a positive move toward ratification.

The Bill provides for the Commission to consist of 17 members, namely: A chairperson; three members nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions; three members nominated by the Confederation of Australian Industry; one member nominated by the Premier of each State and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory; one member nominated by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations; one member nominated by the Minister for Health; and one member nominated by the Minister for Territories. The emphasis on consensus in the operation of the Commission is underlined by the requirement that there be 12 affirmative votes before a decision can be made by members.

The Bill provides for the Commission to function in two divisions to be known as the National Occupational Health and Safety Office and the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety. The national office will be the operational arm of the Commission, providing the secretariat and policy development functions, working with the State and Territory governments and playing its part in the dissemination of information. The National Institute will be the technical and scientific arm of the Commission. It will carry out research, statistics, specialist training and other matters to be determined by the Commission. The Director of the Institute will be a statutory appointment. While the National Institute's work priorities will be determined by the Tripartite National Commission, the scientific objectivity of the Institute and its work has been protected within this legislation.

In the Bill the scope of the definitions has been defined broadly because the most significant powers being given to the Commission are those of inquiry and information gathering for the purpose of developing appropriate national standards. Under the Bill, 'Occupation' means a full time or part time occupation and includes occupations such as those traditionally recognised as an employee, an independent contractor, a statutory appointee, government service-including the Defence Force or a police force-a member of parliament, a self-employed person, a worker in a family business, or a director. It also encompasses within this definition persons undertaking occupational activities whether or not they work in paid employment, for example, voluntary workers, students, prisoners. These persons are often exposed to injury and illness which is occupationally related.

The definition of 'occupational health and safety matters' means matters relating to occupational health and safety including: The physiological and psychological needs and well-being of persons engaged in occupations; work related death or work related trauma; prevention of work related death or trauma; the protection of persons from work related death or trauma and the rehabilitation and retraining of persons who have suffered work related trauma. This definition is in line with international conventions and practice in other countries particularly in so far as it encompasses the areas of work related stress-a condition all too common in today's modern work force.

Because of the multiplicity of regulations affecting occupational health and safety, one of the important aims of the Bill is to enable the Commission to declare national standards and codes of practice. These will be advisory in character and will only be declared after consultation with interested parties and after interested persons have had an opportunity to make representation. The application of national standards will be a matter for State and Territory governments in their jurisdictions and for the Commonwealth in respect of its own employees, the Australian Capital Territory and external Territories.

As indicated earlier, it is my intention to introduce later this year specific legislation to afford occupational health and safety protection to employees of the Commonwealth and those in the Australian Capital Territory and external Territories. The Commission will be empowered also to conduct an inquiry into an occupational health and safety matter. For this purpose the Commission may appoint a commissioner who may not necessarily be a member of the Commission. In general, the commissioner appointed to conduct the inquiry will be required to provide a copy of the report to the Commission and the Minister to enable the Minister responsible to provide a copy of the report to the House within 15 sitting days of receipt of the report. The commissioner's powers will be broadly those exercised by the Industries Assistance Commission in its inquiries.

There is provision in the Bill for the inquiry, or part of it, to be held in private if the Commissioner is satisfied that this is desirable in the public interest because of the confidential nature of any evidence. The commissioner may direct that publication of evidence be restricted or prohibited. The Bill affords protection of the commissioner and witnesses in the conduct of an inquiry. The commissioner will have the same protection and immunity as a justice of the High Court in the performance of duties and any witness will have the same protection also. No employees appearing as witnesses or giving evidence at such an inquiry could be dismissed or have their employment prejudiced because of their appearance at an inquiry. Nor could an employer threaten to dismiss an employee because that employee proposed appearing as a witness or giving evidence at an inquiry. For anyone contravening this provision the Bill provides for fines similar to those of comparable bodies. It is fundamental to the Government's philosophy that the principles of openness and participation are basic elements of our national occupational health and safety strategy. This is reflected throughout the Bill in the dissemination of information functions required of the Commission.

As mentioned previously, the Commission will have the power to establish a research trust fund. This will enable the Commission to assist research by an individual as well as by Commission staff, and to provide funds for organisations to assist in implementation of the national strategy. It will also promote the joint funding of Australian research into occupational health and safety referred to earlier.
Conclusion

The Federal Government has demonstrated the ability to achieve uniformity of legislation in many areas. The national companies code is one example. We are confident that we can work with State and Territory governments, unions and employers, to develop uniform national standards for occupational health and safety to rectify the serious neglect of past Federal governments and to work in a spirit of co-operation. Regardless of party or politics, there is every philosophical reason why society should be as protective of men and women in their working environment as it is with regard to the food they eat or the non-working environment to which they are exposed.

The time is long overdue for the construction of a national framework of action. Other countries such as Canada, the United States, Britain and various other European countries have been implementing major programs but we have lagged behind despite the general belief that we are among the most advanced countries in the developed world. This Bill, and the Commission which it sets out to establish, will provide the national framework and a positive impetus to collective efforts to improve the working environment of all Australians.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to allow the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee greater flexibility in setting the rate of special levies on local cargo. I will now explain briefly to honourable members the background to this Bill. The stevedoring industry is characterised by a high degree of labour mobility between employers and ports, labour pooling in some ports and rotation of labour through terminals in major ports. These are important factors in ensuring efficient labour utilisation and higher industry efficiency. These factors also make central funding of many employer obligations the practical and cost saving alternative to individual company arrangements and complex portability provisions. As a result of this, the stevedoring industry has a long history of levies on employers to fund these centralised arrangements. Successive Federal governments have been involved in the industry since 1942. Although that role has been substantially reduced as a result of agreement reached at the National Stevedoring Industry Conference in 1976-77, the Government still provides statutory support for certain levy arrangements agreed between the parties.

In determining rates for the levies for which it is responsible, the Government acts on advice from the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, which is made up of representatives drawn from the industry. Other non-statutory levies are managed by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour. At present, there are two types of levies applied in the industry-statutory and voluntary industry levies. There are currently two types of statutory levies:

One is a general levy on man hours which finances employers' retirement fund contributions, long service leave provisions, administration costs, the port conciliator service and, in non-permanent ports, attendance money, guaranteed wage and retainer and annual leave; and

The second is a special levy on tonnages and on man hours employed on bulk cargoes, which has been used to pay out the undischarged deficit of the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority which was wound up in 1977.

Various voluntary levies are imposed by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour to cover sick leave, annual and long service leave provisions, early retirement benefits, idle time, and ancillary labour redundancy and long service leave provisions. As with the statutory levies, these apply both to cargo tonnages and man hours.

Between 1977 and 1984, redundancy in the stevedoring industry was financed through voluntary levies imposed by the AEWL, with local cargo levied at 20 per cent of the rate applicable to overseas cargo. This differential rate reflected a much greater contribution by overseas cargo to the technological and trading pattern changes that have contributed to redundancy in recent years.

In 1984, amendments to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act 1977 enabled the SIFC to fund redundancy through an increase in the statutory special levies. This allowed the SIFC to refinance an existing AEWL loan and take on responsibility to fund identified redundancy in the industry. However, section 7 of the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act 1977 requires that local cargo be levied at 75 per cent of the rate applicable to overseas cargo. This essentially reflects the relative contribution to the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority deficit referred to above. This compares with the 20 per cent differential applying under the voluntary levies.

Consequently, the amendment currently before the House seeks to amend section 7 of the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act to provide discretion to the SIFC to recommend a rate of levy on local cargo-loaded-less than 75 per cent of the rate on overseas cargo-loaded and unloaded-should the Committee see this as appropriate. This would allow the redundancy component of the statutory special levy to be set closer to the initial 20 per cent.

The exercise of this discretion by the SIFC is appropriate for several reasons. Firstly, with the long-standing 'industry deficit' now fully amortised, the special levies will, from 1 May 1985, solely provide funds to meet repayments of borrowings made to finance redundancy in 1983 and 1984. Secondly, scope to allow a reduction in the levy on local cargoes will offer some relief to those operating the coastal trade. Coastal operators at present are facing severe competition from road and rail transport and an improvement in their cost structure will assist the industry in providing a more cost effective service to its customers.

Honourable members should note that an increase in the special statutory levy on overseas cargo will be necessary to maintain sufficient funds to meet the Finance Committee's obligations. However, this increase will be small because the special statutory levies apply to a far greater volume of overseas cargo than local cargo. In 1983-84 the levies applied to approximately 23.9 million tonnes of overseas cargo and 4.9 million tonnes of local cargo. Furthermore, any such increase would be more than offset by the overall reduction on the special statutory levies which will occur as a result of the amortisation of the industry deficit component of those levies. As I have indicated, this is currently scheduled to take effect on 1 May 1985.

There will be no cost to the Federal Government as a result of this amendment. The Government believes that this amendment represents a further step along the path of improving the efficiency of this vital industry. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Scholes, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957 to modernise the structure of the Commission and make it more accountable and responsive to both the Government and the Australian Capital Territory community. The Bill seeks to do this by replacing the Commission's corporation sole with a board of seven commissioners and by inserting a ministerial power of direction clause.

The amendments proposed in this Bill arise out of the report of the Committee of Review of the role and functions of the National Capital Development Commission-known as the White Committee-which was tabled on 21 September 1983. That report found that the National Capital Development Commission, as established in 1957, had been an outstanding success in transforming what was then described as a 'bush capital' into the national capital it is today. It did, however, recommend that a community of a quarter of a million required different and more democratic structures then were necessary in 1957 and proposed a representative board to replace the existing Commission, to balance national and territorial interests.

The Government believes that decisions on most of the Committee's recommendations should be made in the context of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The particular matters covered by this Bill are framed in such a way as to be compatible with future decisions on self-government, and should therefore proceed now. Further, a restructured Commission will facilitate speedy action on the remaining recommendations once the final decisions on self-government have been taken.

Under the proposed amendments, the Commission's corporation sole will be replaced by a seven-member board, comprising three full time and four part time members. Of these, at least two will be drawn from the local community and at least one from outside the Australian Capital Territory. The Government considers a more broadly based structure than that recommended by the White Committee is appropriate.

Currently, unresolved policy disputes between the Commission and the Minister are referred to the Governor-General-in-Council for resolution. Notwithstanding that there has been only one such situation in the past 25 years, it is a cumbersome procedure for the resolution of disputes and conflicts with the Government's policies on the role and operations of Commonwealth statutory authorities and the provision of adequate accountability and ministerial oversight. Consequently, this Bill seeks to amend the Act to include a ministerial power of direction. However, the Government rejects the White Committee's recommendation for use of the 'Commonwealth Bank model' of policy direction as an appropriate mechanism for the resolution of disputes. That model would be even more cumbersome than the present power, and would be inconsistent with practice elsewhere.

This Bill provides that directions would be issued by the Minister only after consultations between the Minister and the Commission had failed to resolve a particular matter and would be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and, subsequently, in the Commission's annual report. Such powers of direction are a feature of the enabling legislation of other statutory authorities such as Telecom Australia and the Parliament House Construction Authority. It is anticipated that, as in the past, such disputes would be rare indeed.

The House will be aware that last year the Government made an in-principle decision on self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The Government will be considering a more detailed proposal shortly. The changes proposed in this Bill are consistent with any move to self-government, particularly in terms of a more broadly based decision making structure for the Commission. The Bill has no financial impact. I commend the Bill to the House.
