It is the first national scandal of the second Hawke socialist Government and it will cost it dearly at the next Federal election, mark my words!

The former Minister for Housing and Construction, now the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), cannot escape unscathed. He was the man who went right around Australia and said: 'Look at this wonderful thing, the first home owners scheme'. Of course, that scheme was originated by the Fraser Government, but the former Minister picked it up quickly and he ran with it. On l6 November last year, three days after his Leader deceived the people of Australia from the Opera House, the former Minister said: 'We introduced the first home owners scheme and brought home ownership within the reach of thousands of young Australian families of limited means'. He is now winging his way to Europe to tell British and European migrants that they really are welcome in Australia after all. He would be interested to know that his successor, the present Minister, in a conspiracy with the Prime Minister, has now brought in a Bill which will effectively put home ownership out of the reach of thousands of young Australian families. I believe that these mostly young people-some of them are old people-will remember for a very long time the way this Minister came into this Parliament last week and almost boasted about the fact that he was first cab off the rank in the Government cuts. He tried to sell it as a virtue.

The day before the Minister came into Parliament to do that there was a selected leak to the Australian. Mr Paul Ellercamp wrote a front page article which said, effectively, that there were going to be cuts of about l0 per cent. Of course, we have now had a chance to look at the figures. I tell the first home owners of Australia that the lowest cut is l4.28 per cent-nothing like l0 per cent-and the highest cut is 23.53 per cent. So much for the deception of a 10 per cent cut. The cuts range from 14.28 to 23.53 per cent. This Minister, with the Prime Minister, has now put home ownership out of the reach of thousands of Australian families.

To make it even worse-I will prove that this is so-the heaviest cuts will fall on the poorest and most needy members of the community. Is that just? The cuts that the Hawke socialist Government has brought in in this Bill are going to hit the poorest and most needy members of the community the hardest. What a bunch of hypocrites they are. I will demonstrate that, because of the Minister's rush to the chopping block to volunteer himself as the first sacrificial lamb for government cuts, he did not stop to look to see where the cuts were going to fall. He has effectively brought down the axe most heavily on the poorest and the most needy, the underprivileged and the pensioners of Australia. Those with the most limited means are going to feel the most severe cuts of the Hawke-West conspiracy and their dreams of owning their own home will evaporate.

Before I turn to the Bill, let me put aside one furphy which was raised, firstly, by a journalist in the Parliamentary Press Gallery-a literary genius called Mr Russell Barton who writes for the Melbourne Age or, as some would have it, the Spencer Street Pravda. That was followed yesterday in this House by a member-he is a nice fellow, but he has not opened his mouth for months-putting a dorothy dixer to this Minister. The furphy they started to run around the traps was: 'Big split between Howard and Hodgman'. What a lot of poppycock. I ask the Minister to check the Hansard record and see whether he can find one word in my remarks in response to the Minister's statement in this chamber last Tuesday criticising cuts in government expenditure. He will not find it. If he reads the Hansard record he will find that I made three fundamental points. The first point was that the Minister and the little Caesar of Australian politics, the current Prime Minister, had set a world record in breaking a solemn election promise within l6 weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—I thank the honourable member for his interjection. It is a shameful situation, particularly when we remember the way in which the Prime Minister spoke at the Opera House and the way in which the former Minister spoke all around Australia. How many votes does the Minister think the Government would have lost if last November it had told the people of Australia that within l6 weeks of the election it was going to cut the throat of the home owners scheme, that it was going to cut the throat of its own baby? How many votes does the Minister think the Government would have lost if it had come clean?

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good the Minister pretending that he did not know. He was not appointed Minister until about 8 December, but it was about 8 December that the Department of Housing and Construction found out that it had already committed about 75 per cent of the total funds for l984-85. The Budget was only 20 weeks old and the Department was suddenly starting to run out of money. What happened then? We had the famous memorandum which I read from the other day; the memorandum which went out, with the Minister's approval, to Mr J. Wisken, the Regional Director for Tasmania and Victoria. That memorandum set out ways and means of fobbing off applicants and delaying the processing of applications. It even proposed a draft letter with a blank: 'The delay in your case will be . . . weeks'. I criticised that and at the same time I criticised the Prime Minister's action in going to the National Housing Industry Association's Twentieth Convention in Canberra on 30 March and reading out a speech, but leaving out three nasty paragraphs so that the delegates to that convention did not find out the bad news until the next day, when they read the full speech in the newspaper. The Prime Minister of Australia is quite happy to give the good news but he does not have the guts to stand up and tell people the bad news. The Minister was at the luncheon. He was at the next table to me. He must have writhed with embarrassment. I do not wish to be unfair, but the Prime Minister is not very tall; nevertheless, I was able to look across and see him at the podium-it was a very large podium-as he was going through his speech. I wondered why he was shuffling the pages like somebody shuffling cards. Of course, we found out. The following day the nasty bits were in the Press. The full speech had been given to the Press, but the Prime Minister did not read it all to the delegates at the convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't want to be booed.

—The honourable member is quite right. I am quite certain that when the Prime Minister goes to the next Housing Industry Association convention, if he is still Prime Minister next year, which I doubt very much, the Housing Industry Association is going to say: 'Listen, Robert, next time we want you to read the whole of the speech'.
—Nothing but the speech.

—The honourable member is quite right. The plain fact is that one of his aides said afterwards: 'I'm awfully sorry; the Prime Minister ran out of time'. I give the Prime Minister a bit of friendly advice: If he wants to retain his reputation for integrity-and he is running out of time-he should leave out all the self-congratulatory pieces and read out the bad news. The third thing that I said was that it appeared at first blush that the cuts were going to fall hardest on those who could least afford them. The very next day the shadow Treasurer, the next Treasurer of Australia, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was in the chamber talking about the overall budgetary situation and the economic prognosis. He said quite categorically that in budgetary terms he had no argument with the cuts in the first home owners scheme. Mr Russell Barton of the Melbourne Age then said: 'Ah, ha, there is a big split'. He wrote an article in the Melbourne Age which was reproduced in the Hobart Mercury. Nobody else in the Press Gallery saw this big split. Mr Howard, very promptly, the following day, wrote a letter to the Mercury making it very clear that there was no split at all between him and me. To put the matter beyond doubt, so that even my friend Mr Russell Barton will not get it wrong a second time, I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst accepting the need for overall budgetary cuts in Government spending, including in the First Home Owners Scheme, the House condemns the Government for- (a) introducing this Bill which amounts to a shameful dishonouring of an election pledge to maintain the First Home Owners Scheme, and
(b) its arbitrary action in determining that the heaviest costs would fall on the poorest and most needy members of the community'.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—We hear squeals from Government supporters. The squeals that we hear from them are nothing compared with the squeals that are coming from the first home owners of Australia because they now realise that they were conned. The figures themselves show what a disgraceful situation we have on our hands. Let me give honourable members opposite some examples.
—Since when have you been concerned about the poor?
—Oh, we hear the man who abstains, the honourable member for the Coburg Town Hall. He is the one who abstained the other day.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Every time the honourable member makes those sorts of remarks about honourable members I will ask for them to be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order.

—Do members of the Hawke socialist Government approve of the fact that joint home purchasers with an income of less than $l0,000 per annum will suffer under option three a cut of 23.5 per cent? Two pensioners in receipt of less than $l0,000 a year will be subjected to a cut of 23.5 per cent. Do honourable members opposite agree with this? I ask the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), who is a great champion of the homeless in her electorate, to tell me what she thinks about this. Under option three a single applicant with no children-in many cases a young employed female-will have her grant cut by 23.53 per cent. This is a drop from $4,250 to $3,250. If she takes option two, the cut-this is for someone on a salary of only $l0,000 per annum-is 22.22 per cent. If she takes option one the cut is 20 per cent. Why is the Hawke socialist Government saying to the young women of Australia who want to purchase a home on their own account: 'You have been singled out. You are earning only $l0,000 a year; you are going to be chopped'?

SPEECH.PARA: A young single mother or a deserted wife who wishes to apply under option three will be subject to a cut of l7.39 per cent-that is, from $5,750 to $4,750. Let us take the case of a single home buyer without dependent children. If the income is $l3,000 per annum that home buyer's grant under option three will be chopped by 23.5 per cent. On option two the grant has been chopped by 22.27 per cent and on option one it has been cut by 20.03 per cent. Why has the Government decided that the heaviest cuts will fall on the poorest and most needy members of the community? Is it because the Government did not do its sums, or does it not care about pensioners who cannot get homes? The Government does not care about single mothers with children. It does not care about the battlers and the underprivileged.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do about it? Tell us about your scheme?

—Would the honourable member for Aston, the man who lasted less than one round at the Coburg Town Hall the other day, be interested to know that whilst the Government has increased spending for housing by 70 per cent since March l983, in real terms the funding for pensioner housing in Victoria has been cut?
—No.
—If the honourable member does not believe me he had better talk to his own welfare agencies because they know, as I do, that it is true.
—You have never been near a welfare agency in your life.

—Honourable members opposite are yapping and yapping. We had a deputation in this Parliament only two weeks ago. The point was made very forcibly in the office of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) by welfare housing groups in Victoria that as a result of the mismanagement of the Hawke socialist Government, aided and abetted by Mr Cathie and the Cain socialist Government, the amount in real terms for pensioner housing in Victoria has been cut in l984-85. This shows the absolute cant and hypocrisy of those on the other side of the House in the Hawke socialist Government who say: 'We really believe in housing; we really want to help these people.' They bring in a first home owners scheme; they pump it up, they get all the publicity they can for it and l6 weeks later they cut its throat. The chickens will come home to roost.

SPEECH.PARA: The Indicative Planning Council has told the Minister that housing commencements have peaked, that they have now flattened out, that they will drop before the end of l985 and that they will continue to drop in l986. According to one set of figures the Minister has effectively chopped $l5.37m off the appropriation for the first home owners scheme for next year. The cut will be the same as the inflation figure of 5.3 per cent because the Minister has simply repeated the same figure of $290m that was given for l984-85. However, that figure becomes $40.37m if we add the $25m which the Minister let slip in his ministerial statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—The Minister says 'rubbish'. It is like what happened yesterday. The Minister can say 'rubbish' as much as he likes. The first home owners of Australia are awake to him.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say in passing that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), who is a very genuine member of this Parliament, has drawn to my attention a letter which I will read in a moment. The letter concerns a young couple in his electorate whose grant will be chopped as a result of actions of this heartless Minister and this deceitful Government. I will read the honourable member's letter to me, excluding only the names of the young couple because, with respect, I would not put it past someone to try to victimise them. The letter states:

Dear Michael, I am writing to provide you with details of how the Minister's reduction of the limit of the First Home Owners Scheme has affected my constituents, Mr and Mrs . . . West Ryde. A letter which I have sent to the Minister for Housing and Construction is attached.

First inquiries indicated that only those applicants who had exchanged contracts would be eligible to receive the maximum $7,000 grant. However, I have since been in touch with the Department's Sydney office and received information that the Minister has, in fact, indicated to them that they have the discretionary power to approve applications which are close to contract exchange if the details of the case warrants it in their opinion.

In Mr and Mrs . . . case, they are already fully extended as far as their borrowing capacity goes and I think it would be appalling if this young family lost their chance of home ownership due to the Minister's recent announcement. I shall keep you informed of progress in this matter.

That letter was written 24 hours after the Minister's statement was made. I have had phone calls in my electorate office asking why the scheme has been cut out. The changes have been so badly presented that many people think it has been cut out. I have had to explain on behalf of the Minister's Government and his Department that it has not been cut out completely but that it has been cut back.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I come back to the basic and fundamental point. You, sir, are a man of honour who would not go around the electorate before an election promising things which could not be honoured and 16 weeks later turn around and up those promises. The Minister received a warm reception, even though he did not speak, at the twentieth National Housing Industry Convention. He will get a very hot reception next year. We know what the Minister is going to say and, with the greatest respect, without his cue cards he is not all that hot. The Minister is going to say that the Housing Industry Association of Australia welcomed and accepted the cuts because they would lead to a reduction in interest rates. That is quite true. But what did the National President, Mr John Graham, say in his address, which was heard by the Minister? He called upon the Government, in the interests of dependability of policy, consistency, fairness and equity, not to change the scheme. I ask the Minister the $64 question: Did he have the courage to tell Mr John Graham and the directors of the Housing Industry Association of Australia while he was at the convention that barely l6 days later the industry's throat would be cut and that applicants would find their grants reduced by l4.28 per cent, and in some cases up to 23.5 per cent? Did the Prime Minister have the courage to point it out? Honourable members know that the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry has already said that housing commencements will drop before the end of this year. That means that jobs will be lost in the building industry and retrenchments will take place.

The Government will accelerate that process because, as a direct result of its actions and its breach of promise, it is now creating a situation which will lead to many thousands of Australian workers presently in the housing and building industry being out of jobs before Christmas this year. What about the heartbreak the Government is bringing to the young people of Australia who were conned by it and by a Prime Minister who proclaimed to the world: 'And we are going to keep it that way'? He called in the Minister for Housing and Construction and said: 'Stewart, you are the first cab off the rank'. Stewart said: 'Yes, Prime Minister'. He did not fight. Had I been the Minister for Housing and Construction I would have put my job on the line because this breached a fundamental election promise. Even accepting, as I do without any equivocation whatsoever, the need to cut back government spending-even under the first home owners scheme-had I been in government, I would have taken this right down to the line, because I would not want to be part of a shabby, crooked and dishonest government which tears up election policy promises 16 weeks after making them. I certainly would not want to be part of a government which said that the heaviest cuts were going to fall on the poorest and most underprivileged.

I challenge the Minister, when he replies, to explain his rationale. When he looks through his figures he will find that it is the poor people in the community who are really getting the heaviest cuts. Why is it, for example, that applicants on $20,000 a year and with one dependent child will suffer a cut of only l5.38 per cent but the single home purchaser, who could be a young woman on an invalid pension, will have a cut of 23.5 per cent? What is the Government doing? Is it playing up to the Tooraks and Vaucluses? Where is its sense of social justice when it takes a stock whip to the poorest? The Minister should never come into this Parliament again and say that his Government cares for the underprivileged, the poor and the needy. He should never parade his conscience on his sleeve. He should not say, as the Prime Minister said: 'We are here to look after the little people of Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the motorists.

—Exactly. In its first l985-86 cuts, the Government has belted the poorest, and it does not seem to realise what it has done. In conclusion, the amendment accepts the need for overall budgetary cuts in Government spending, including under the first home owners scheme, but we condemn the Hawke socialist Government and the Minister-in particular, we condemn the Prime Minister, because in my book he is more guilty than even the Minister-for bringing in a Bill which amounts to a shameful dishonouring of an election pledge within l6 weeks of its being given and for taking an arbitrary decision with the effect that the heaviest cuts will fall on the poorest and most needy members of the community. Shame on them! The Government stands condemned. I believe that, if there were an open and free vote in this House, the amendment moved to the motion for the second reading would be carried, as, quite frankly, it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) once again with his pseudo moral indignation over what this Government is proposing in the housing area. Evidently, he has been a shadow Minister for Housing and Construction for far too short a time to be aware of his own Party's track record when in government. If he bothered to bone up on his Party's antics in the housing area throughout its seven years of government, he could wax morally indignant with perfect sincerity. I am sure he will remember that the then Treasurer introduced a housing policy statement which included a one per cent increase in the rate for savings bank owner-occupied home lending, and a one per cent increase in trading bank interest rates for overdrafts of less than $l00,000. The statement was not so much about housing as about an increase in all the regulated interest rates, not just for housing, but also for overdrafts. The then Treasurer introduced a one per cent increase-a further step in the continual upward trend of interest rate increases which so dogged the economy under the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: An attempt was made to sugar-coat the bitterness of yet another interest rate increase in the housing area. The key proposal to soften the blow was a tax rebate for some home buyers. One only has to look at the figures to recognise the con game. The total impact of a one per cent rise in interest rates was not offset by the scheme. The cost of the rebate scheme was $230m but the cost of the interest rate increase was $300m. As well, the then Treasurer admitted that only 28 per cent of home buyers would qualify for a rebate, so that 72 per cent-about l.2 million people-received nothing but a higher interest rate bill on their homes. In fact, 450,000 households covered by the scheme represented l0 per cent of all households. Under the previous Government 90 per cent of them received no sugar coating at all-just a bigger pill. As the interest bill went up over two years $1.2 billion came into the coffers but home buyers received only $230m back. They were $l billion worse off under the previous Government's policies.

Even the family man with a wife and child who received the maximum rebate was $l0.45 a week worse off. If the honourable member for Denison wants to whinge deceit, he should look at his own Party. We bitterly criticised the increase in interest rates at the time but the most interesting criticism came from the Opposition's ranks. It came from the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). I quote from page l2l0 of Hansard of 18 March 1982:
. . . it seems to me that this is obviously-the statement and the intentions-a collision between political necessity and economic reality.
He continued:
. . . I believe this scheme falls far short of where it should reach.

He was bitterly opposed to what his own Party was introducing. In 1975 the then Prime Minister said that he would not interfere with the housing interest rate deductibility scheme. In 1976, he wiped it for everybody but the first home buyers. In 1977, he wiped it out altogether. The honourable member for Denison should consider that for a moment. That was just one more of the 30 broken promises collected during those seven years.

Before the honourable member for Denison tries to make political capital out of the First Home Owners Amendment Bill and its provisions, let him ponder his Party's deplorable record in government, particularly in the area of housing. The history of housing under previous Liberal governments has not been happy. In February l982, the Victorian Housing Minister, now the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, showed publicly and clearly what he thought of the Federal Liberal Government's attitude to housing, in particular to welfare housing. He called on the then Prime Minister to provide more money for housing in Victoria or to keep out of the Victorian election campaign. I quote from the Herald of 20 February l982 in which he was reported to have said:

If the Federal Government does not recognise the plight of the community here in Victoria and in Australia as a whole, then I would be very concerned as to the value of any Federal Minister participating in a campaign here in Victoria.

That is strong criticism from within the honourable member's Party, totally endorsed at the time, and still, by every Labor member in this House. We then saw the Victorian Minister for Housing and the Federal Minister for Housing trading abuse and frantically trying to duck-shove responsibility for the tragic decline of public housing in Victoria and in Australia. Mr Kennett described the l982 Budget allocation for public housing as an absolute disgrace and accused the Federal Minister of deliberately misleading the public.

In retaliation, the Federal Minister accused Mr Kennett of arrogance and insincerity. Strangely enough, although they were poles apart in their opinions, they were both right. At that time the Federal Government applied a continual squeeze on finance for public housing and callously abandoned thousands of families who were finding great difficulty in paying high rents. Paragraph (b) of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Denison and seconded by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) states that the Government's arbitrary action would fall heaviest on the poorest and most needy members of the community. Both gentlemen do not really understand the poor and needy, who are the ones who are paying high rents in private housing because honourable members have failed, both in the States and federally, to provide welfare housing or public housing. I read from Hansard of 24 August 1982; it is what I said to members of the Opposition when they were in government:

Because of this concentration on the needs of home buyers, the difficulties of both private and public tenants have been largely ignored. The trends within the housing sector should be seen in a broader context-a massive shortage of public housing and a dramatically shrinking private rental sector, together with a serious decline in the housing industry. It is essential in any discussion on housing that it is recognised that the housing sector has been permitted to operate on the basis of a fundamental inequity-a substantial proportion of the population has been denied any access to home ownership and has been forced to live in an unregulated private rental sector or grossly inadequate public rental sector.
People on low incomes, on pensions and on unemployment benefit-
I say this for the benefit of the honourable member for Denison-
are increasingly disadvantaged by the increasingly high rents they are forced to pay. The Government's-
that is the previous Government-

housing policy is an example of the neglect of the poor and needy by the Government's economic policies. It has been produced as a major contribution towards enhancing high private ownership. Not only will it not achieve this objective, but its effect will be to exclude even more Australians from owning or renting a home.

The Labor Government's first home owners scheme has been a key element in the remarkable recovery in the housing sector. When the first home owners scheme was announced housing activity was at a 20-year low. In l982-83 there were only 105,500 dwelling commencements; in 1983-84 there were 137,000, a dramatic increase. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry expects l47,000 commencements in l984-85. The Government also expects improvements.

Over 430,000 people are employed in the housing and construction industry. It contributes 7 per cent of the nation's gross domestic product, is a key sector of the economy and is an important catalyst to economic recovery. The Government recognises this, even if the Opposition does not. Expenditure on housing and construction is an investment in the future. The benefits do not stop there. As almost all the inputs are supplied by the Australian industry, it has strong linkages with other sectors of the economy. Small and large Australian industries gain from an increase in construction activity, which has a high employment multiplier.

I am not surprised that after the honourable member for Denison spoke in the House he had many telephone calls suggesting that the Government had put an end to the first home owners scheme. From the way in which he spoke one would have thought that the Government had decapitated the scheme altogether. I refer to the Press statement of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) in which he said:
As from midnight, April l6, the maximum benefit under the Scheme's payment options and dependant categories will be reduced by $l,000.

Masses of intending Australian home owners will still benefit under the first home owners scheme. The Government rejects the carping from the honourable member for Denison. For over two years its economic and housing policies have been helping Australian families. Those policies have helped the housing and construction industry, they have got thousands of people back to work, and they have bumped productivity. Against a background of the Liberal Party's policies, particularly in the area of public housing, the Government has worked a miracle.

We intend to reduce the deficit and we do not resile from taking the tough decisions necessary to do so. I congratulate the Minister on having worked out a proposition that will keep the first home owners scheme operating in the interests of the housing and construction industry and the people of Australia. However, we intend to ensure that eager would-be home buyers do not suffer and that the industry maintains the vigorous activity it has shown under a Labor government.

I totally reject the comments of the honourable member for Denison. He obviously has not yet come to grips with his shadow portfolio of housing and construction. That is understandable; he has not been in it for very long. However, I assure him that we will remain on the government benches for long enough for him to at least understand the fundamentals about housing, which are that the poorest sections in the community never get an opportunity to own a home. When we do not increase money allocated for public housing we force them to pay high rents to private owners. The Minister has shown enormous responsibility in this area and I congratulate him. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In May l967, which was many years ago, I made my maiden speech in this place on the subject of the home savings grants scheme. When one listens to the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who is at the table, and to Government members one gains the impression that the first home owners scheme-FHOS-was the first one ever introduced in this country. I turn back to l963-some 22 years ago-when Sir Robert Menzies announced the first ever home owners scheme in City Hall, Brisbane. So the scheme is not a new arrival. People listening to this debate and others should bear in mind that all the Government has done is simply shuffle the pack, give the scheme a new name and say: 'That is our brilliant new scheme'. The Minister is smiling. This happened before his time, but that is what has gone on in this country.
—At least there is not a l2 months delay.

—I concede that point because I am a generous man in conceding improvements, but by eliminating the l2 months delay the Government has had to wipe $l,000 off the top. I remember that in February l983-it was five days after the end of that February that I lost my seat of Fadden-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) traipsed around this country giving his solemn word to my constituents and the rest of Australia, who were conned, that a Labor government would retain the rebate schemes and other incentive schemes for people buying homes. The Minister is again smiling. It was a little Mr Magic; first you see it, then you do not. Bang! On l3 November l984-this was mentioned by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman)-the Prime Minister was at the Opera House, although it was more of a comedian's performance. He referred to the first home owners scheme and to what the Labor Government was doing. Then-here is the quote of excellence-he said: 'And we are going to keep it that way'. I can almost hear that promise being made. Unfortunately, a bare majority of Australians believed him. However, I believe that the good will which exists in this community is fast running out.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Housing and Construction has not given Australians a thing. To finance the first home owners scheme the Government got rid of three pre-existing schemes which were not supposed to be removed. First, as from 30 June l983, it abolished the housing interest rebate scheme which was introduced by the Fraser Government in l982-83. The special home loan interest tax rebate scheme, which was introduced in March l982 for first home buyers, finished in October l983. Then the Government wiped the home deposit assistance scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was it worth?

—It was worth $l06m for the nine months it was in place. The Government, by wiping those tax rebates, saved itself over $300m. I heard a very interesting justification for that by the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), who told us a few minutes ago that the assistance was going in the wrong direction, but not everybody was being assisted. The fact is that the Government clawed back over $300m from the people. I am not referring now to the level of income which those people were on. The Government took more than $300m from the people, which is something it promised it would not do. The Government shuffled the pack again, dealt it out and then introduced certain limitations. All it did was remove the requirement that people had to save so much money to qualify for assistance and then introduced income levels. Having reshuffled the pack, the Government redealt the cards and said: 'Aren't we marvellous?' I concede, in my generosity, that there are some people out there who would never have been able to save the original deposit as required under the previous Government's scheme.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member for Aston laughs, but it is true. The newspaper headlines which we read now indicate that some of these poor people who were enticed by the Government's scheme are now losing their homes because factors which are crumbling down upon their heads are preventing them from continuing their repayments. They are simply walking away from the dream that was put there by the Government's scheme. I say to the Minister-I say this objectively-that I hope his Department is monitoring the situation very carefully because it may well be that he will have to re-examine the extent of fatalities along the way in terms of success. The housing industry was in a disastrous situation because honourable members opposite, when they were in government, could not manage the economy and did not care about housing. The Housing Planning Indicative Council has indicated that the years ahead are not as certain as the year we have gone through. It is a sleight of hand by the Government. The Government makes extravagant promises and then, in a furtive way, dishonestly withdraws commitments. The Government makes loud claims and then makes secretive decisions at a later stage about those claims. The Government cannot have it both ways. Under this Government interest rates are rising, with people in need of homes, and the Government has made a decision that will put the housing industry into a dive over the next two years. The Prime Minister's words will not stand; there is no way they can. There is no way that this Government can deliver on the promise:
We are not offering a grab-bag of unrelated, unachievable election promises.

The Government made the promise to maintain housing at a level of 145,000 a year or at about that level. The Government will not achieve it and it will drop back substantially. The average loan in Sydney at present is about $50,000. The average interest rate for a housing loan is 13.5 per cent. That is the highest real interest rate individuals have paid for many years. If one takes the average cost of living and the average cost of putting a home together, one finds that the most significant real cost is the cost of money-the cost of getting hold of a loan to have a home built. This scheme encouraged young people to consolidate their finances and establish a home for the first time. The Minister for Housing and Construction is making significant and drastic changes to the scheme at a time when he should not be making those changes. It is completely the wrong policy.

I agree with my colleagues that there needs to be a restraint in Government expenditure, but this is not the area in which to do it. There are many other areas to which the Government can apply restraint. To use the housing industry, a significant sector of the domestic economy, to which to apply this restraint is not the right way to go. The Government should mark my words. We will be here in 12 months time and we will make a comparison then. The Minister can chuckle; he may think it is a great joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell me which areas you suggest.

—Although the Minister is flippant and nonchalant about this proposal, the fact is that average weekly earnings around Australia are at different levels. In New South Wales average weekly earnings are $403-which is right on the margin for the first home buyers scheme. In Victoria the figure is $385; in Queensland, $370; rising to $434 in the Northern Territory and $449 in the Australian Capital Territory. Already many people are beyond the range of this scheme. As time passes, with the brakes the Government has put on to the scheme, the small amount of assistance the Government will be giving will mean that if the average loan for a person in Sydney is $50,000, paying 13.5 per cent, the Government will put a first home beyond the reach of first home buyers. This scheme was a good scheme; it consolidated previous government schemes. It used about the same amount of money, so the claims the Government has made for it are not realistic because the previous Government was putting the same amount of money out in housing, or slightly more. The present Government consolidated the scheme. That is fine; it is a good scheme, but now the Government is spoiling it and changing it at the wrong time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am fearful as to what the Government will do to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. It is inconsistent, it cannot be relied upon, and the Government's word is not its bond. The cost of materials has not increased greatly over the last 12 months and, based on that alone, the Government could hold the line. The cost of labour component has not risen greatly, except for the strong unionisation of the home building industry in New South Wales which is occurring and which, by the way, will increase costs in that industry by 25 per cent. That figure of 25 per cent is from the Housing Commission of New South Wales. However, let us set aside the cost of labour.

What about the cost of money-the cost of borrowing? It is now as high as or higher than it has ever been. That is the highest it has been for years. That is the factor that is not under control. That is the factor that is worrying the international community. The Government can congratulate itself for introducing a good scheme. I join the Government in that, but I am extremely critical of it for making changes to the cycle of home building in Australia at a critical time. It has been a worry and a concern of the housing industry of Australia that there is cyclic activity-booms and busts year after year. TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Whitlam years.

—Like the Whitlam years, it will be up every two or three years and down again after that. The Government has had a boom. It is heading for a very low level of activity. I have explained the reasons. As members of the Government they can dismiss that. I suppose the Labor members' fetish for being loyal to their Party means that they must do that. It means that the Government must do that, but mark my words, right at this moment it is facing a most dangerous condition in the housing industry, brought about by this decision. It indicates a wish to cut expenses willy-nilly in a major sector of economic activity.

SPEECH.PARA: I am extremely disappointed with the attitude of the Minister and the attitude of the Government. It is claimed that it is a cost cutting measure. The fact is that it will be a cost-cutting measure that will result in fewer people purchasing their first home in the next 12 months than there have been for a number of years. The boom and bust cycle of the home building industry is about to recommence. I regret that. The Government should be strongly condemned for it.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australian Labor Party was returned to office in 1983 we inherited a situation in which the Fraser Government, the Liberal-National Party coalition Government, had deliberately run down the Commonwealth's commitment to putting Australians in their own homes. As anyone with experience of that time will recall, at that time those who did receive the benefits were those who were more affluent. That cannot be denied. People on lower incomes found it increasingly difficult to bridge the deposit gap. Hence, more and more of these people saw their hopes of owning their own homes drift further away. What made things worse for them, of course, was the disregard that the Liberal-National Party Government had for the public housing stock. At a time when the economy was running down we heard these strange noises about the evils of government intervention in the economy in every aspect. Had the Liberal-National Party Government had the wit and had it been less blinkered by its viewpoint, it would have recognised that the building industry was a fundamental industry into which an injection of funds would result in a range of benefits greater than would occur with any other industry.

Prior to the introduction of the first home owners scheme the situation in the building industry was nothing short of critical. To use a favourite adjective of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), the Government of which he was a member was guilty of shameful neglect of the industry and was guilty also of having deliberately forced this industry into recession. Thousands of tradesmen in the industry were thrown out of work and as a result, of course, their wives and children suffered appallingly. Many communities suffered from a decrease in available funds, resulting in even more people being thrown out of work. The building industry is a classic industry. Not only is it labour intensive, but also it generates many jobs in feeder industries. It also provides much needed money to inject into service industries, manufacturing industries, road construction and community business.

In communities such as Ararat and Ballarat in my electorate, the effects of the downturn in the building industry were felt most keenly. Today the situation is remarkably different. In every aspect of the domestic building industry the level of business has improved-and improved markedly. The prime factor in this dramatic recovery has been the Government's first home owners scheme. To illustrate the way my electorate has benefited I illuminate the following figures: From 1 October 1983 until 11 April 1985, 935 applications were approved. The amount of benefit paid to home owners is $2,822,000. The amount of benefit approved to be paid over the five-year period of the grant is $4,458,000. Not only are these people in their own homes-or will be in their own homes-much sooner than they would have been under the niggardly and inequitable scheme of the Liberal-National Party Government, but also the funds generated by this scheme have provided a much needed injection of funds into the local economy and, of course, into job creating possibilities.

Assuming that each house is valued at $40,000, the amount injected into the economy is in excess of $37m. Together with homes that would have been built anyway in the region, this represents a massive contribution to the regeneration of the economy in the Ballarat electorate. I put to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the figure of $40,000 per home is a conservative estimate, because the average cost of homes purchased is considerably higher than that. From 1 October 1983 to 21 August 1984 the figure was $49,958 and from 22 August 1984 the figure is $46,969. When the total figures for the first home owners scheme are taken into account the Australian total of approvals for the above period is 123,663. When translated into benefits paid, this represents an outlay of $373,434,000 in benefits approved and $602,331,000 in forward grants. This brilliantly conceived program has led to the creation of 55,000 new jobs in the building industry alone. In terms of jobs and new dwelling commencements, the program to date has outstripped expectations.

As the Minister indicated in his second reading speech, around 147,000 to 150,000 dwellings will have been commenced during this financial year, which is an increase of some 40 per cent since the Labor Government assumed office in 1983. While I am mentioning the increases in dwelling commencements, I feel compelled to comment upon a statement made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in which he claimed that fewer people own their own homes in Australia today than was the case when the Government assumed office. As with so many other statements made by the honourable member, this is wide of the mark. It is a pity the honourable member is not a little more careful about the way in which he makes his statements. He knows full well that there is no evidence to support his claim. It is with regret that the Government has felt obliged to reduce the grant available through the first home owners scheme. As I have indicated, the Government has been more than pleased by the success of the scheme which has helped many people to overcome the deposit gap and to obtain a home much sooner than they might otherwise have expected.

The Bill before us seeks to reduce the size of the grant. It also seeks to make a number of minor adjustments to the scheme in respect of obvious anomalies. The reduction in the size of the grant has become necessary as part of the Government's program of trimming the deficit. While this might disappoint a number of people-it probably disappoints us all in a way-it is important to remember that a blowout in expenditure would be counterproductive. It would not only result in serious inflationary pressures but also increase interest rates. Therefore, I believe that most people will accept the decision, although it is tough, because they will recognise it as a sign of responsible, and not weak and opportunistic, government. It is interesting to note that the Housing Industry Association of Australia has also come out clearly and supported the Government's position.

In conclusion, this legislation is of vital importance to all of those who aspire to own their own homes. The Government has very firmly reasserted its commitment to the first home owners scheme. Vast numbers of first home owner scheme application forms and accompanying information have been distributed from my electorate office. Members of my staff have assisted many people in their applications. They have been particularly happy to co-operate with lending agencies, real estate agents and solicitors in an endeavour to make it easier for people to acquire a home. In fact, my electoral assistant has held seminars along those lines with members of those industries so that they also can assist people to gain the advantages of this scheme. I assure my electorate that this service will continue as will this scheme. While I am sorry that the grant has been decreased I am confident that the scheme will continue. Therefore, I ask the House to reject the amendment and support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) had to say about the First Home Owners Amendment Bill 1985. Let me start with one of the negative effects. The original Bill, and the continuation of the scheme, in effect raises the cost of housing for all Australians. That is something that should be noted. People who move from one place to another, people who change their lifestyles and younger couples who are buying a home for the first time all face higher housing costs. That implies that they will have to make a greater investment and consequently, over time, they will face a higher interest bill. That is one of the negative effects.

Before honourable members opposite start congratulating themselves on the positive effects they should bear in mind that the majority of Australians in the longer run will pay more for home ownership. This will happen in two ways. Firstly, of course, the price of a limited supply of land will be bid up as more people come into the market place. That, by itself, has probably wiped out most of the extra funds that are made available under the first home owners scheme. Secondly, of course, the cost of building a house is being increased in areas which face capacity constraints. These effects, of course, are already being felt most by the exact people whom the Government claims it is trying to help. Most people purchase houses which cost somewhere around two and a half to three times their average annual earnings. The people the Government is trying to help are earning incomes between about $10,000 and $27,000. I now refer briefly to the southern part of my electorate, which includes the suburbs of Woodridge and Kingston, and which is generally referred to as Logan City. The Institute went on generally to laud the scheme. Let me deal with several specific points made during the debate. As I said, I was puzzled by the division and the lack of cohesion in the Opposition position, but what I found simply impossible to understand was the allegation, which is included in the amendment-it is one of the reasons we will not accept it-that the cuts bear hardest on those who can least afford to pay. The Opposition has misunderstood the way in which the $1,000 cut affects the amount paid under each category of applicant and each payment option, because the lowest percentage cuts have gone to single or joint applicants with two or more children. The figure is 14 per cent under option 1, 15 per cent under option 2, and 16 per cent under option 3. The highest percentage cuts have gone to single and joint applicants with no children. The figure is 20 per cent under option 1, 22 per cent under option 2, and 24 per cent under option 3. Let me cite the figures again so honourable members opposite will understand them. Single or joint applicants with no dependent children, under option 1-taking the subsidy over only five years-will now get $4,000. That is a cut of 20 per cent. Single or joint applicants with two or more dependent children will get the $6,000 over five years, down from $7,000-which is a 14 per cent cut. I could go on. If one cuts $1,000 off the highest figure-obviously it is a lower percentage cut than $1,000 off the lowest figure-it becomes a higher percentage cut. The people who are getting the lower figures are those with no dependants. So there is no rationality in paragraph (b) of the Opposition's amendment.

The Opposition said also in the debate that we were engendering a boom-bust set of conditions in the industry. This sits very strangely indeed with the people who, in 1982-83, achieved the lowest level of housing construction in Australia for 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —No boom for them; just bust.

—No, they had their boom two years earlier when there were 149,000 starts. They sent the industry through the floor in just two years, the figure reaching 105,000. We have gone in the other direction. I said yesterday that the Indicative Planning Council was predicting 147,000 starts, but we are now informed that the figure could be 150,000 due to the high level of lending, the high level of approvals during December and January and the high level of commencements, comparing the December quarter of 1984 with the December quarter of 1983. So I am revising that figure upwards a bit. We look like getting 150,000 this year, but we certainly expect that that will continue on to an average of at least 139,000 or 140,000 next year. So bouncing down from 105,000, bringing it up to 150,000 and then holding it at around 140,000, which we can continue to expect, is a lot different from the situation which existed under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesmen also alleged that somehow or other the $25m cut had become $41m. Let me patiently explain again what happened. Last year in the Budget we said that we would allocate $265m under the standing appropriation in this Budget and that would allow some 80,000 applications to be approved. In the event, earlier this year we found that we were running over the Budget appropriation and that we ought to let the situation run. The Government decided that it would make an extra $25m available which would be enough to approve, as fast as practicable given the staff we have on the job in the Department, all those which ought to be approved, meaning we would get 87,000 applications approved at a cost of $290m this year. That is the position. When we looked at the next Budget, the decision of which I have already announced, we found that the revote would cost about $315m, given the existing guidelines and the continuing number of applicants being constant. The $1,000 reduction across the board, which I have already announced, results in a saving of $25m, bringing the appropriation down from $315m to $290m. So there is no $41m involved. The $290m is assessed to be enough to cover the existing forward assessments of the number of applicants who would be approved, except they will be getting $1,000 less. There is no shonky arithmetic in what I am telling honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fiddle.

—It is not a fiddle. We appropriated $25m more in 1984-85 than we said we would in the last Budget. We said we would allocate $290m. I am informing the House and the people of Australia in advance of the position. We have not kept the decision to ourselves. We have an enlightened approach to budgeting procedures. We think it is not appropriate to keep these Budget decisions to ourselves for six months while people, aided and abetted by the Opposition, speculate as to whether the scheme will continue. Once we made the decision we felt the appropriate thing to do was to announce it in order to kill any speculation that the scheme might be killed off and to reassure the people who were in line for a grant that they would still receive it and that there would be no changes for people who were already the recipients of grants or who had already contracted to buy their own house. We cleared the air. I make no apologies for the fact that we will get the full year's financial effect of the saving.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying that there was no boom-bust mentality in the housing policies of this Government. We have been able to achieve a remarkable recovery in the housing industry. This year we will get the highest level of approvals and the highest level of commencements. We will have built the largest number of public housing dwellings and we will have put the largest number of low income people into housing in many years. Over the past 12 months the number of housing loans has increased by 26 per cent across all significant lenders. We have achieved that remarkable 50 per cent recovery in a non-inflationary way. In the three months to January, the building industry materials prices index has risen by only 0.8 per cent-0.3 per cent in January, 0.2 per cent in December and 0.3 per cent in November. That is a second remarkable achievement.

In addition, this increase in housing and construction activity, since it was achieved in such a non-inflationary manner, has resulted in a great boost to employment. The figures from August 1983 to February 1985 show that in the housing and construction industries combined we have created an additional 83,000 jobs in that period-48,000 jobs in the period from August 1984 to February 1985 and 30,000 in the past three months. That certainly shows that we have been able to get a far greater kick into employment through the housing industry than through any other industry sector in the Australian economy. When we achieved office early in 1983, the unemployment rate in the building industry was 14 per cent. It is now 7.3 per cent. There is only one State in Australia where the unemployment rate in the building industry is higher than the national unemployment average. There are no prizes for guessing which State that is. It is Queensland. Unfortunately, Queensland currently has an unemployment rate in the building industry of 11.7 per cent compared with the national average in the building industry of 7.3 per cent. That compares with 4.3 per cent in Victoria. I digress by advising the Premier of Queensland that, given the deleterious economic situation he is facing, the confrontation with the trade union movement in Queensland is not helping the Queensland economy at all.

To conclude, I must reject the spurious arguments that have put by the Opposition in attacking our position on the first home owners scheme and most emphatically reject the Opposition's rather silly amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak on clauses 2 and 10 of the First Home Owners Amendment Bill. I will speak to them at the one time thus saving the necessity for two speeches by myself and two replies by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). It is a matter of profound regret that the House has just voted to defeat the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we have present in the public gallery boys and girls from the Grammar School at Sale, Victoria. Therefore, I will explain this matter in very simple terms so the listeners of Australia will know exactly what this deceitful, dishonest Government has done. Before the last election the Government promised $1. However, on 16 April the Government said that it was not a dollar after all but only 80c.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Only 80c! The Government has cut back on the home savings grants by an average of 20 per cent. I note that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) is in the chamber. I remind him that clause 2 of the Bill provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: Sections 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9 and 14 shall be deemed to have come into operation on 17 April 1985.

The Bill therefore is technically retrospective. However, I do not stay to debate that. It means that the election promise to maintain the first home owners scheme has been broken. Here I quote Robert James Lee Hawke, the impostor who on 13 November 1984 said in the Opera House: 'And we are going to keep it that way'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member to refer to the Prime Minister as the Prime Minister.

—Madam Chair, I will refer to him as the Prime Minister for the time being; the Prime Minister on the way out and the Prime Minister who will not even be leading the Hawke socialist Government by Christmas this year. The Special Minister of State grins. The Prime Minister is on his way out because the people do not believe him any more. What is the point of a promise made on 13 November which is torn up in shreds by 16 April 1985? I am sorry to say that the Minister for Housing and Construction, who said that our second reading amendment was silly, is being conned because he is basing his whole argument on clause 10 of the Bill. Clause 10 of the Bill amends section 34 of the principal Act. The Minister has been conned into believing-just as the first home owners of Australia were conned into believing that the Prime Minister would keep his word-that he will get $290m in 1985-86. What does this clause say? There are two quite independent Queen's Counsel in this chamber who will listen to these words and decide whether the Minister is to get his $290m or not. Clause 10 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 34 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:. . . .

'34. (1) Subject to sub-section (2), assistance payable after the commencement of this section and before 1 July 1985 is payable out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is appropriated accordingly.
There is no problem with that. However, let us look at sub-section (2) which states:

(2) Assistance payable under sub-section (1) shall not exceed, in the aggregate, an amount that, together with the total amount of assistance paid on and after 1 July 1984 and before the commencement of this section, is equal to $290,000,000.

I see the look of amazement on the face of the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). There is no promise of $290m. The Bill states that the amount shall not exceed $290m. Unless the Minister has it in writing his chances of getting that $290m must be looking a little shaky. If the Minister is prepared to put his trust in the honourable member for Wills, the Prime Minister, so be it; but he is one of a rapidly reducing and speedily dying bunch. If the Minister so proudly thinks he has the $290m, why did he not insert in the Bill the grants to be applied for 1985 so that he could have said to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when he returns from explaining himself overseas: 'You cannot change the grants any more because the figure is locked into the Act'? But that has not occurred. The first home buyers of Australia will be staggered to find, when they receive a copy of the First Home Owners Amendment Act 1985, as it will become, that it does not say what their entitlement is.

So what do we have? Tomorrow the Minister for Housing and Construction might be shifted again to another portfolio. He has made as much of a mess of the Housing and Construction portfolio in four months as he made of the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio in two years. The Minister does not have one word of statutory authority for his statement that grants will be maintained at the level that he has announced. The Prime Minister made a promise on 30 November to the effect that he would keep the first home owners scheme the way it was and 16 weeks later tore up that promise and chopped the scheme. He is cheating the first home owners of Australia by cutting their grants by 23.5 per cent. The Minister has said: 'I was the first to be responsible'. He went willingly to the block. He should have fought right down the line.

I put it bluntly that the Minister waffled when he gave his answer. He said nothing about the broken promise. He did not in any way answer the strong arguments put forward by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), who gave an outstanding speech, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who gave the sort of speech that we expect of him, the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) and, last but not least, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). I am proud to have led Her Majesty's loyal Opposition in this debate with such an outstanding team of supporting speakers whose contributions were very different from some of the speeches that were made by honourable members opposite. One of the Minister's colleagues said that we should be very grateful that the scheme is still on foot. That is rather like saying: 'Thank God, we have not been murdered; we have just been raped'. The attitude of the Minister's colleagues was to say: 'It does not matter very much'.

In conclusion, I want to read into Hansard the explanatory memorandum. I am not having a shot at the officer who drafted it, but this is what was given to us as the explanatory memorandum in relation to this Bill. I will read it because every prospective first home purchaser will laugh his or her head off when the names of Hawke and West are mentioned and these words are remembered. The explanatory memorandum states:
The purpose of the Bill is to provide for a number of machinery amendments of minor policy significance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no!
—It is true. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . of minor policy significance or of a routine administrative nature, and to provide for a fixed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote it?
—I think Bob Hawke wrote it. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to provide for a fixed appropriation to contain expenditure under the First Home Owners Scheme to within Budget appropriation.

We have a Bill that does not guarantee the Minister his $290m. We have no statutory provision which guarantees any first home owner that after the Budget is brought down he will get the amounts that the Minister announced one week ago. There is no protection. We have a guaranteed situation of retrenchments in the building industry and in the housing industry as the direct result of what the Minister has done.

I say to the Minister that, whatever else his failings may be, I would have thought he would have seen this to be an issue that is critical to the first home owners of Australia. He has even boasted in this Parliament that this year there will be 150,000 new starts and next year there will be 146,000. Yet he does not admit that that is a drop. If he cannot tell the difference between up and down, he is just as hopeless as a government which cannot tell the difference between $1 and US62c. Before the Minister replies, I challenge him to refute what I have put. He has no guarantee of receiving his $290m. The first home owners of Australia do not trust him. They certainly do not trust the Prime Minister. I ask the Minister to take back this Bill, redraft it and bring it back in proper form. I plead on behalf of the first home owners and the housing industry for the Government at long last to do the right thing and not betray thousands and thousands of decent Australian who stupidly trusted it before the last election and now realise that they have been betrayed, deceived, conned and let down shamefully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — As this is a major matter for the Australian community, it is necessary for members on this side of the chamber very briefly to put the record straight. When it comes to the question of deceit and of misleading the Australian community, the Opposition should be very careful because its performance when in government in relation to housing was lamentable. It is very clear-and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) should remember this-that under the previous Government housing went down to a 20-year low. So it is no good for the honourable member to talk about ups and downs. When it came to getting things down, the honourable member and his crew did a magnificent job of tearing the bottom out of the housing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that must be emphasised when talking about keeping faith with the Australian community is that, if the honourable member for Denison had the patience to talk to people who have actually received grants under the first home owners scheme, he would recognise that their entire housing circumstances were changed by this scheme and by the scheme that preceded it. The third thing that must be said when we are talking about performance of the housing industry is that very clearly the industry is performing exceptionally well. As the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has indicated previously in this place, we are looking now at a very high level of starts-147,000 is the figure which the Indicative Planning Council has indicated. Clearly we will achieve that target. The honourable member for Denison should be more interested in consulting the industry rather than giving histrionic performances in this place. It is very clear that he has not consulted the industry. He has not spoken to the people with whom we have been speaking in the last couple of weeks. If he had consulted the industry, he would be in a far better position--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I raise a point of order.
—I am pleased to see that the honourable member is actually conscious.

—Along with the Prime Minister, who spoke on the Saturday, I was the official speaker at the National Housing Industry Convention in Canberra and for the honourable member to say I have not consulted--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—For the honourable member to say that he was the official speaker for the Opposition does not indicate that he consulted the industry and it certainly does not indicate that he has learnt anything, or he would not be giving such an abysmal performance tonight. That must be made very clear. We are looking for the Opposition to put forward a housing policy. The honourable member for Denison knows that it does not have one.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of the $290m, we indicated that we are heading this way and that we have set the closing date at midnight on 16 April to stop a run on the scheme. It is a very simple explanation which the honourable member cannot seem to get in his mind. We will take him through it very carefully. The reason why we set the closing time of 16 April was to stop a run on the scheme. I also add that it stops people such as the honourable member talking down the industry, which is what he is doing now. The honourable member, in the same way in which he tried to stir up the immigration debate, is trying to talk down this industry. It will not work because people in the community have more sense than that. The honourable member might want to give histrionic performances. The reality is that the scheme has been accepted by the community generally as being a substantially sound scheme. It is being continued. The Government is committing itself to providing $290m in the next financial year and that is a substantial performance.

All I need to say is that when we are talking about an issue of such major concern as housing the record of this Government is substantially sound, not only in terms of people getting their own homes but in terms of job creation and managing the financial community. The Opposition's problem is that it does not have a housing policy. All we have is the memory of a very poor performance when it was in government. All that we need to say with respect to this legislation is that the amendment to the scheme which was proposed by the Opposition is nonsense. All that the Opposition has done is to reiterate the same nonsense over again and the community is aware of it. Housing recovery is under way. The Minister's position is very clear. He has been successful in terms of what he has fought for in respect of housing and the industry has acknowledged this point. If the honourable member for Denison was in contact with the Housing Industry Association, the Master Builders Federation of Australia and other associated institutions, he would recognise that point. We do no have to speak at great length about this matter. We do not have to have histrionics. All we have to do is to lay down the factual circumstances. I do so to try to clear the record because many Australians are concerned about housing and so is this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. In response to the comments of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), I have made inquiries about the housing industry and I have been advised that it is anticipating that 9,000 potential home buyers will be unable to buy a home in the next year as a result of the cuts that are being made here this evening. I sincerely believe that the money the Hawke Government has clawed back from the community is more than paying for this present scheme. The Government has perpetrated a great con act on the Australian people. It has taken more back than it is giving, even at the most generous moment of the savings on the first home owners scheme, which is simply an alteration of one of the Fraser schemes. This Government merely said to the people: 'We no longer require a deposit'. The Government also introduced income limits in terms of how much a person could earn to qualify for assistance. Although Government members seek to talk down the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), I believe that he has really put his finger on something and that a great con act is being perpetrated on this country. It is a reflection on the integrity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Prime Minister stood up before the 1983 election and the 1984 election and said: 'We will not touch any of the existing schemes'. All the Government seems to do is to rip into the little people out there, and Ministers smile while they are doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has spoken during this Committee stage debate of previous schemes under the Fraser Government. That was most unacceptable to people who wanted the money to buy their house-to provide the deposit and pay on settlement. Its successor, I think, was the home deposit assistance scheme. The Opposition talks about this Government bringing our scheme back from $7,000 to $6,000. The previous coalition Government had a limit of $3,500. Not only was the limit $3,500, but those concerned had to have a record of 12 to 18 months savings before they could even apply. Our scheme is applicable straight away. When Labor got into office, the Labor Government said that it would put a ceiling of $5,000 on the scheme. In the event we made it $7,000, but at $6,000 we are still well above what we promised back in March 1983 during the election campaign.
—That is not true.

—That is all true. I want to wind up this debate by repeating what I said in my second reading speech on this Bill. I said that if this Bill were passed, we would say there would be no further changes to the scheme in 1985-86, and that we would appropriate $290m to fund it in the next Budget, which would be enough to fund up to the present expected numbers, taking into account the change from $7,000 to $6,000. I conclude by repeating-I do not say this in a nasty manner-that the Opposition has fundamentally misunderstood the procedures we have adopted. The statement simply said that we were reducing the amount of the grant by changing the regulation of the current Act. The major part of the Bill is clause 10 which amends section 34 of the Act to change the standing appropriation after 1 July to an annual appropriation so that we can control the payout during 1985-86 to $290m, which I have already flagged as the budgetary figure. It also allows the standing appropriation to continue until 1 July and allows us to put a ceiling on the 1984-85 figure at $290m, the same amount as we intend for 1985-86.
